title: Ticket #2437: CRON job object state not marked idle after forced termination
description:
There seems to be a bug in the state handling of the cron object. The cron job takes too long to complete because of the system state. When the startd tries to fire off the next periodic cron job, the startd kills the one that is still running. The state of the cron object for the one still running gets changed to CRON_KILL_SENT. The reaper changes this state to CRON_DEAD, but there doesn't seem to be a mechanism to transition the state to CRON_IDLE or CRON_READY. In the next periodic cron job, the cron object's state is checked against CRON_IDLE and CRON_READY, but since it's CRON_DEAD, CronJob::StartJob returns with the "not idle!" message.

It's easily repro'ed with 

  STARTD_CRON_NAME = CRON
  STARTD_CRON_HOME = /opt/condor/bin
  CRON_JOBLIST = JRTCRON
  CRON_JRTCRON_EXECUTABLE = $(STARTD_CRON_HOME)/jrt
  CRON_JRTCRON_PERIOD = 5
  CRON_JRTCRON_RECONFIG = false
  CRON_JRTCRON_KILL = true


  $ cat /opt/condor/bin/jrt
  #!/bin/sh


  /bin/sleep 1d
====

• cron.patch 969 bytes added by jrt on 2011-Sep-01 20:30:30 UTC.
    Patch for fixing up state in the reaper.

    The main problem is that CRON_*_SENT ends up being changed to CRON_DEAD which is a dead end state for the CRON object. The reaper shouldn't be called unless the process is dead. If that is the case, then the reaper should change the state to CRON_IDLE in all cases. If KillJob and the reaper is triggered due to the cron destructor, the ending state is irrelevant. But the ending state must be CRON_IDLE for subsequent periodic runs of the job.
